posts.name: Corey Applegate
posts.cooked: Has anyone successfully and can share how to connect Rev Robotics or any other magnetic Limit switch to the CTRE Limit inputs. In our case the Solder pads on a CTRE Magnetic Encoder. It seem to me that we Need a 3 or 5 vdc source to get things working.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
It needs power (Red wire, 3.3 to 5 Volt), ground (black wire), and provides a digital output (White and blue, wired together internally, according to the data sheet).  It has an internal pull-up resistor. CTRE motor driver: get power from pin 1 (3.3 Volts to the red wire), pin 10 for ground (black wire), and then wire either the white or blue wires to the limit you want (pins 4 or 8).  That should do it.  You could instead use power from pin 2 (5 Volts); I don‚Äôt think it will make much difference.  I am a bit mystified why they used a blue LED; those take more voltage than just about any other LED‚Ä¶

I haven‚Äôt actually used it, but I‚Äôm fluent in ‚Äúelectronics‚Äù and ‚Äúsensors‚Äù

posts.name: bobbysq
posts.cooked:
Weldingrod1:

I am a bit mystified why they used a blue LED; those take more voltage than just about any other LED‚Ä¶

It‚Äôs an extension of the simple Computer Light Performance Enhancement Theory:

Red LED = Goes faster Blue LED = Runs cooler Green LED = More energy efficient

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
Soldering to the pins on the small 10-pin connector is tough.

There‚Äôs a related discussion here: Connecting a Magnetic Encoder and a Hall Effect to TalonSrx .

posts.name: Corey Applegate
posts.cooked: I have seen that thread. Short answer is the effort to make it work out weighs just using a hard switch

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Oh, sorry, should have mentioned it.  There‚Äôs a couple different nice little breakout boards available for hooking stuff up to the CTRE drivers, or you can cut a grey cable and solder to the wires.  You really don‚Äôt want to try to solder into that fiddly little insulation displacement connector!!!

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
Weldingrod1:

nice little breakout boards available for hooking stuff up to the CTRE drivers

I‚Äôve used this one to good effect for several projects.  You can solder directly to it, or use pins and Dupont connectors.

CTR-Electronics was founded by Mike Copioli and Omar Zrien in 2006. Our goal is to provide robust embedded solutions for various robotic and control applications.  We have successfully designed products on multiple processor architectures while...

posts.name: Corey Applegate
posts.cooked: All good ideas but our issue is we are using the MagEncoder as well on this device. We ended up making a flag and used a mechanical switch.

posts.name: James
posts.cooked:
Something you might want to check out for the future:

Littlefuse sells magnetic proximity sensors in a variety of different mounting options.

I like these threaded ones as you can easily adjust the spacing from the magnet by adjusting some nuts. They‚Äôre cheap too, so worth having a few on hand. Cart filler for the next PDV.

https://www.digikey.com/short/11jvd0dm

Just a two wire contact closure. Should be a drop in replacement for a mechanical limit switch. These have been out go to for end of travel /position indications for the past ~4 years

They also make the lower profile rectangular ones in the same product category.
